newsitem.title: JAPAN: SPEED SKATING-NIEMANN, POSTMA STEP UP TITLE HUNT.
newsitem.headline: SPEED SKATING-NIEMANN, POSTMA STEP UP TITLE HUNT.

text.p: German Gunda Niemann and Ids Postma of the Netherlands enhanced their prospects of overall titles with victories at the world speed skating championships on Saturday.
Niemann won the women's 3,000 metres and came close to breaking speed skating's oldest record in leading a German sweep of the 1,500 metres.
The five-time Olympic medallist holds a 1.782-point overall lead over team mate Claudia Pechstein, silver medallist in the 3,000 metres and bronze winner at 1,500 metres.
Postma increased his margin over Japans Keiji Shirahata to 0.540 points with a win in the mens 1,500 metres.
"If I feel the same way tomorrow, I think I can win the competition," said Postma, silver medallist at last year's championships.

American K.C. Boutiette, who trailed Postma by 0.75 seconds, was third overall. A former roller blader, Boutiette took up speed skating three months before the 1994 Lillehammer Olympics where he finished out of the running but decided to devote himself to the sport.
"I think it's crazy to come second after three years of skating," Boutiette said.
Niemann clocked two minutes 0.51 seconds in the 1,500 metres, the second-fastest women's time ever recorded. Team mate Anni Friesinger finished 1.49 seconds behind.
East German Karin Kania-Enke, the only woman ever to break two minutes for 1,500 metres, set her record of 1:59.30 in 1986 at Alma Aty before the break-up of the Soviet Union.
Annamarie Thomas of the Netherlands was third in the overall standings after finishing fourth in the 1,500 metres and sixth in the 3,000.
The top 12 skaters compete in the men's 10,000 metres and women's 5,000 on Sunday to decide the overall titles.
